Finding an eye-catching way to ridicule the Secretary of the Interior, Donald P. Hodel, is this week's sport in the House of Representatives.

Mr. Hodel outraged many members of Congress by suggesting last month, at a meeting of President Reagan's Council on Domestic Policy, that hats, sunglasses and sun screens could be effective alternatives to an international treaty as a way of protecting people from the ultraviolet radiation reaching the earth because of depletion of the ozone layer. His proposal for ''personal protection'' was seen by opponents as undercutting a tentative 31-nation agreement to reduce the use of the refrigerants, solvents and aerosols that are destroying the protective ozone layer.
On Monday, Representative Thomas J. Downey, a New York Democrat, appeared on the House floor wearing a big hat and dark glasses. ''These are the new weapons,'' Mr. Downey said.

On Tuesday, two more Democrats, James H. Scheuer of Brooklyn and Patricia Schroeder of Colorado, played a verbal duet on the subject. Mr. Scheuer brought to the floor a half-dozen poster-size cutouts of animals, including a lion and an owl, decked out in hats and sunglasses. Their point was that animals, too, would need ''personal protection'' from ultraviolet rays under Mr. Hodel's approach.
When Mr. Scheuer noted that his lion looked ''very natty'' in a safari hat and sunglasses, Ms. Schroeder observed: ''I fear he looks terribly wimpy, though. It may make him very angry.''
After agreeing that animals could scarcely be expected to spread suntan lotion on themselves, the two suggested a ''buddy system'' under which animals could learn to spread lotion on one another.
